Posts.Content: Hi Celia Fantastic news!  Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: ALL CLEAR

Posts.Content: Hi Clair I didn't do the scalp cooling treatment as I read the literature and decided it wasn't for me. Basically I didn't want to spend the extra time at the hospital. Throughout my treatment I have met many ladies who have had varying stories of success. Not one of them has told me they regretted trying it, even those who still went on to lose their hair. If it's important to you, and that's what counts, then it's worth trying. Because I wasn't trying the scalp cooling I was actually fitted with my wig before I started chemo. An appointment was made for me to meet the 'wig lady' at my chemo unit but practices may vary. You get one 'free' wig on the , never ended up wearing mine as I never felt right in it but it was gorgeous and looked good.  I have met lots of people that have bought themselves several styles on line and said they're not too expensive.  Hope all goes well with the cooling, just keep the wig for back up, the chemo nurses can make an appt I'm sure Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: Starting EC and advice on scalp cooling please!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tess You're so right, I met a few of those along the way. 'Good girl' was one of my pet hates, I'm 45, not ben a 'girl' for quite some time. I respond better to the let's get on with it attitude because that's the way  am too. My daughter is 16 next month and loved the shocked faces when people saw my bald head. I was a great source of amusement for her! Max xxx
Posts.Title: Starting EC and advice on scalp cooling please!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Clair No-one thinks you're vain. It's a very personal decision that only you can make. As i've said it does take longer but so worth it if it's what you choose to do. I haven't particularly been treated differently by anyone but then I haven't acted any differently. Strangers have probably been kinder or more considerate but no-one that knows me changed. You will need to tell them at your meeting that you want to use the cold cap and mention the wig thing too. Stay positive and strong it doesn't last forever and passes pretty quickly. Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: Starting EC and advice on scalp cooling please!!!

Posts.Content: Hi I had a mastectomy, chemo, RT and Herceptin over the last 18 months. My node clearance showed cancer in 13 out of 19 removed. My post-surgery scan was clear and I've had none since. At my final Oncology appointment I asked about a scan because to me it seemed logical to do one once treatment was complete. I was told that because my post-op scan was clear they just assume that the rest has done it's job! I have never heard the words ' all clear', NED etc they don't seem to say it, not sure why, but anyway I'm just getting on with life now and happy to be able to do so. Hope you can find some answers to settle your mind Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: scans after Herceptin?

Posts.Content: Hi Gitte I think that because once we're diagnosed everything moves so fast that we don't have time to process it all. We don't allow ourselves to think about what is happening as we need all our strength to focus on treatment. However once treatment is over I think we finally allow ourselves to think about what has happened and it can be a difficult time. I had what I called a 'dark' period but fortunately it didn't last long and I'm sure yours won't either. Once the dust has settled on it all you will pick up and feel much better about it all. But be assured from the many people I have talked to this is quite a normal way to feel and no, it's not just you so don't beat yourself up about it. You don't have to be bursting with the joy of every new day, for one thing people would probably think you were mad! Just allow yourself time to deal with it all. Hugs Max xxx
Posts.Title: post cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sally I had a mastectomy last year followed by 7 cycles of chemo and 15 of RT. I am now halfway through 18 cycles of Herceptin and on Tamoxifen for 5 years.  It's ok to feel scared, everyone does mostly it's a fear of the unknown. We worry what it will be like to have it, how it will make us feel. I promise you it won't be half as bad as anything you're imagining. No-one gets all the side effects but we all get some. The best advice I can give you is to tell your team everything you suffer from as they can offer help with everything, if your pills don't work, tell them and they'll try some different ones. Please do not suffer in silence, it's hard enough without suffering anything you don't need to! On the plus side, I have now been back at work 4 months and it's like I've never been away. You will come out the other side of all this crap and life will be back to normal before you know it. Look after yourself,  wishing you strength and remember just because you have a little weep now and then it doesn't make you weak. Let it out and come back fighting. Love and hugs Max xxx
Posts.Title: New to group- so scared of whats to come...

Posts.Content: Hi Clair I had 15 rt and it started three weeks after chemo finished. It can be tiring but more the going every day than the actual treatment. You do get pulled and pushed around a bit but I was very lucky the staff I met were all wonderful. I was treated with kindness and respect by all who treated me. My rt was also at a diffrent hospital to my chemo and a bit of a trail but as Tess says see it as a sign that treatment is coming to an end. Soon you'll be back at work and it will all be behind you. Love Max xxx P.S. My tattoos are very tiny and barely noticeable xx

Posts.Title: Radio after Chemo queries...!

Posts.Content: Hi  I had 4 EC followed by 3 Docetaxol last year. I have to say the Tax did hit me much harder than the EC. I suffered terrible joint pain with it but once painkillers were prescribed it was more bearable. I had the woolly mouth but not thrush and generally felt crap. The side effects are horrendous but you will get through it it just probably doesn't feel like that now! I have a friend who is having it at the moment and her side effects were so bad after the first that for her next they are lowering the dose. Perhaps this is something your team may consider if your side efects become too bad. Wishing you the strength to get through. Hugs Max xxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel - hard work for me.

Posts.Content: Hi all I did have one chemo and one Herceptin in affected arm as veins were absolutely shot in the other arm. Although I had been told it's not ideal my onc said it would be ok as the cannula would be in and out in a few hours. I think it's more if you should be hospitalised and on IV antibiotics that it's not possible to use the affected arm due to the high risk of infection from a cannula that's being left in situ. In a perfect world I think they prefer not to use it and would definitely never take blood pressure on that side. I for one was happy for them to use that arm on those two occasions due to damge to veins in other! Love Max xx
Posts.Title: chemo in affected arm

Posts.Content: Hi I had  right mastectomy 10 months ago and I was quickly back to normal. Definitely within the time frame they gave me which was 4-6 weeks. Your situation is different with having a double mastectomy. Did you receive a chart from breast nurse with various exercises to do? I can't stress enough the importance of doing them. I had days where it seemed like too much effort or that it would make things worse, but honestly they really help. I think the fact that I'm right-handed helped too as I did things and moved it more automatically than had it been my left-hand. Well that's what I put my swift recovery down to! I can still 'feel' it when I lift my arm above a certain height but as this isn't an everyday occurrence, nor does it cause me any pain, I can live with it. I did have some 'cording' but because I was able to move my arm, over time I stopped feeling for it so can't be accurate as to when it went but 10 months on it's no longer there or if it is, its not obvious or detrimental. Wishing you a speedy recovery and hope any other treatment you may need goes well Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: node removal and cording

Posts.Content: Hi  I would expect that it's to give your skin time to heal before RT. If you have chemotherapy after surgery then that takes care of scar healing time as RT comes after chemo. Only thing I can think of. Hope you can ask the right person the right questions and get some reassurance  Max x
Posts.Title: waiting time for adjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Quick update, had my treatment today as expected. Heart function had actually improved from the 54 it was last time up to 64 - so on it goes with no tablets needed. Sometimes just a break is needed and then treatment can be resumed. Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: Heart Problem whilst having Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi  I am also 45 - I had a mastectomy followed by chemo and rt last year. I am currently due my 13th Herceptin and taking Tamoxifen also. I will find out tomorrow if my Herceptin will continue. My Feb heartscan showed a deterioration in function but nothing major and I was showing no symptoms so treatment continued, with another scan booked asap. I have been told that if my heart function has worsened, but only slightly,  I will be put on a tablet but treatment will continue. If the damage is worse than that, which I am doubting as I still have no symptoms, my treatment will stop in order for my heart fnction to repair itself and then Herceptin will resume at a later date. Will let you know how it goes. Max xxx
Posts.Title: Heart Problem whilst having Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi  I had my first chemo in April 2010 and my last period in May 2010. My periods have never returned but at 45 that's not a problem for me. No-one ever has an answer - it could be the menopause or it could be treatment - so I've stopped asking. I realise at your age it's much more of an issue. Love and hugs Max xxx
Posts.Title: chemo and periods !

Posts.Content: Hi I am just about a year on from where you are right now, have my last Herceptin on the 21st July. I went back to work in December 2010 and have just gone fulltime. I too shaved my head once it started falling out. I wore some lovely scarves, all bought in Primark so I could match them with different outfits and it not cost the earth! Never used the wig as I found it too hot and uncomfortable but we're all different with different needs. It's great that we have a choice of what to do. Just wanted to say it will pass, you will both get through it, so stay strong and look after yourselves. Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: hair falling out

Posts.Content: Hi  I'm sorry you have been so ill-informed. I didn't use the cold cap because it didn't worry me to lose my hair, in your words mine was hardly 'my crowning glory' either, also I didn't want to spend the extra time at the unit on what was already a tiring day. Having said that I was offered the option, told it doesn't work for everyone but can be worth a try, given lots of information and left to make my own decision. On the positive side I had the opportunity to 'start over' with no hair colour damage etc, now it's growing back.  I fear like some of the others that the damage has already been done to your hair. Is it really worth the discomfort and time if it's already loose. As with everything it's your decision to make and ask if you really want to. I found it quite liberating having no hair, was not worried by anyone else's looks at my bald head, wore some wonderful scarves on occasion, nothing expensive, primark mostly, and got creative. The wig was never my 'thing' too hot and uncomfortable and never felt I looked like 'me'. Another plus is that after years of shoulder-length hair I have had so many people comment that I would suit short hair, that's the way I may stay. Would I have the courage to try that without this happening, who knows! It's a very personal choice - save your hair/shave it off, wig/hat/scarf, or bald but it's always great to hear what others think. Wishing you well with your treatment Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: Scalp cooling with FEC 75

Posts.Content: Hi CB I was referred to a Breast Clinic in January of 2010, no lump just slight swelling to breast and a little redness that hadn't cleared up with antibiotics. Slightly concerned but not overly worried as there was no lump. Had mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy all in one day but nothing was found. Then the focus seemed to shift from my breast to the lymph nodes, all concerned kept saying they were swollen though, again, here I could feel nothing. What followed was around 5 weeks of going for biopsies, ultrasounds, etc on Mondays and back for results on Fridays. Not complaining was glad to get my results so quickly. Eventually in March I was diagnosed with breast cancer the lump was against my chest wall and I never would have felt it.  I don't tell you this to make you worry but to reassure you that you're doing all the right things and not ignoring things or going away when they tell you you're too young. I am much older than you at 45 but with your family history you should and are being alert. Once all this is done at least you will hopefully be reassured. If the worst comes to the worst and it is breast cancer then like me it will be caught early due to your vigilence and refusal to be fobbed off. Wishing you well and hoping it all turns out to be nothing but never give up if you feel something is wrong. You know your own body, they don't. Love Max xxx

Posts.Content: Hi  I honestly thought you had typed the timings wrong or perhaps misunderstood. I have met many people on her that have had breast cancer, I myself had a mastectomy, but never met anyone with that chemo regime. Posts.Title: side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Are you sure you're having chemo 3 times a week and not every three weeks? I had breast cancer and chemo was 4 cycles of ec and 3 of docetaxol every three weeks. Combination varies by area but still usally every three weeks. Sorry am unable to comment re thyroid problem as I have no experience of that. I hope all goes well with your treatment and that they can remedy the thyroid problem before it starts. Love Max xxx
Posts.Title: side effects

Posts.Content: Hi I had horrendous joint pain for several days of every cycle. I found that co-codamol 8/500 and ibuprofen helped control mine. Think the co-codamol is solpadeine over the counter but got my from docs as it was free that way. Don't always suffer and wait to see your onc about side effects or you'll be suffering unnecessarily. Ring your chemo unit and they can advise you over the phone what will help. The Difflam is great for woolly mouth/sore throat but if you get ulcers/sore mouth then Gelclair is very good, on prescription form doc. Hope things get easier and under control soon Max xxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel-help with side -effects please

Posts.Content: Hi Caz Sorry to hear you're feeling low. I know exactly what you mean. I have never been backwards at coming forwards, nor shy about sharing my thoughts and feelings on any given subject, wether asked or not lol! I returned to work in December last year, after 9 months off having treatment for Breast Cancer, to a job where confidence in what you're saying, a thick skin and determinaion are a must, so you can just imagine how the first few months panned out.... My confidence was at an all time low, feelings of panic when I felt out of my depth, emotional outbursts for no apparent reason! Fortunately, unlike some, my work have been fantastic - 'watching' me but in a good way, stepping in when they could see it was becoming too much, letting me take a breather if necessary and just generally listening to my emotional ramblings some days - that always felt good to let it all out, to say it out loud to somebody and be reassured that I wasn't going crazy. I have noticed that the last few months I have come on in leaps and bounds, feeling good, feeling confident, feeling more like the 'old' me but with a new perspective too. I am now able to concentrate on the things that really matter and let go of the things that just don't! I am no longer 'the woman who had cancer' am just Max. Not that anyone ever made me feel like that, with time and distance I can see it was ME that thought they were thinking that! I think after what you have been through your feelings are completely understandable but I promise you, you won't feel like this forever, it will get better. Just allow yourself the time and don't rush things. Wishing you well Love and hugs Max xxx
